Whoops, this was supposed to go up yesterday (the actual day), but all the info is still good! Every day trans people are subject to violence, stigma, and individual and structural disadvantage because of their gender identity. Their lives are frequently devalued and misrepresented, and their rights overlooked and violated, even within other stigmatized and progressive communities. An appeal for the rights of trans people internationally /// Sign the appeal yourself here /// More info here, on the Questioning Transphobia blog. Awesome blogs for and by trans people: Transgriot /// Questioning Transphobia /// Taking Up Too Much Space /// Bird of Paradox /// Stop Transphobia /// Taking Steps On the home front, the Albertan provincial government recently delisted funding for sex-reassignment/gender-reassignment surgery. I've mentioned this here before, but this surgery is NOT frivolous or unnecessary. The decision to cut it from funding was economic (dubiously so) and political. Facebook group with more info and updates here. UPDATE: Manitoba has *also* decided not to fund for GRS/SRS (it never has, and just rejected a proposal to), despite having and NDP government and a relatively positive economic condition. Ontario tried to pull this shit a few years ago and got pushed back, but the fight never ends.

<u>Early sociological theory</u>: rich white guys defending... other rich white guys.

Karl Marx FTW.

So this is what I'm thinking. It's early May. I've been out of school for a few weeks. Everything went fine, I'm glad to be done, and maybe a little melancholy, but only in an atmospheric kind of way. It's sunny and the humidity is up, but it's still cool out, with a fresh, wet breeze. Winter's not quite gone, and summer hasn't really arrived. I'm curled up in a high-backed armchair, surrounded by windows, a couple of them open just a bit to let that nice breeze on through. In the background Bach is playing. By Yo Yo Ma or Vanessa Mae--I can't decide which. Maybe both. With a little bit of Mae's techno remix style thrown in. I've got one book in my lap and two more on the floor beside me. One of these books is The Last Samurai, my favourite book in the whole damned universe (and it has nothing to do with the Tom Cruise movie). I don't know what the second one is, but the third one is definitely something new, something I just picked up off a shelf somewhere. (The typeface on the spine caught my eye, the picture on the cover intrigued me, and the first couple of pages hooked me. Best of all, it was marked half price because only me and about three other people in the world would ever really want to read this book.) I'm not eating or drinking anything, but about an hour before I had a really lovely tea and scone at a new tea house that opened downtown. (I'm meeting an old friend I haven't seen in a while next week, and I've decided to take her there for lunch before attempting to show her the meagre sights about town.) I feel very relaxed, but as I read my book an energy starts building up and my feet get restless. There's a character in the book that I can't get out of my head and soon I'm going to have to pack up my stuff and go for a walk to try to get my thoughts in order. By evening I'll be writing a fic one-shot and rolling my eyes at my rusty prose, but enjoying myself nonetheless. I won't be able to stay up late, though, because the very next day I'll be starting something new. My summer job, perhaps, or a new volunteer opportunity. Driving lessons possibly. Whatever it is, it's big, and it's going to be taking me to a new level, getting me up and out on my own. But right at this moment, that I am imagining, I am comfortable in my chair, full of delicious tea, feeling the breeze from the window, reading my book in the sunlight, and contemplating this strange, exciting character who just walked into my life. So where are you?

LOOKIT ME POST. Amazing. But also angry right now. PSA: Support and advocacy website fighting back against Attachment Therapy From the site: Attachment therapy (widely known as "holding therapy," "rage-reduction" or "dyadic developmental therapy") is a torturous and entirely unscientific practice that preys on orphaned adoptees, foster kids and children who already have a history of abuse. Attachment therapy techniques rely on forceful physical coercion and restraint, non-consensual touching, verbal abuse, intimidation, enforced eye contact and punishments related to food, water and air intake. It is rejected by the mainstream psychiatric community as "harmful pseudoscience" and is officially banned by several states, but the practice continues to this day in the US and countries around the world. Children have died as a result of this therapy. It has no grounding in research or academic theory, and actually contradicts attachment theory, upon which it claims to be founded. I looked at the videos and read the so-called theory behind the treatment -- it's BULLSHIT. Its aim is complete compliance of children. Any act of disobedience is characterized as a flaw in the child's personality and "attachment", and the therapy itself relies on violence, humiliation, and coercion, not safety, trust, and respect (which is what really attachment theory would recommend). This is a perversion of child-rearing. I don't know about the prevalence of this therapy in Canada, but it is an issue in the US. It is even covered by insurance companies there. This woman, a survivor, is trying to get word out, after finding there were no support groups or general awareness of the harmfulness of this "therapeutic technique". What you can do to help. This shit makes me mad, guys. This goes against everything I've ever learned about effective child care and parenting, from parents, research, and personal experience. Worst of all, it targets adopted and fostered children, some of the most vulnerable kids out there. Warning: child abuse triggers abound. There are links on these websites that lead to graphic (verbal and pictoral) depictions of child abuse.

Basically, what's worth competing over for you? For example, high scores on a test, cash prizes, etc. Can be events, activities, or outcomes. Anything you can think of is appreciated. Thanks!

Every time I check the news, polls are reporting something different. This morning the Tories were in arm's reach of their majority, but now that's uncertain again. Except all the polls are also showing a great deal of potential for change, so a Harper majority isn't off the table by any means. This election outcome is not a foregone conclusion. There's incredible potential for change based on every single vote that comes in. So everyone should be voting! If you're not sure what's what, then Canada's election website gives the skinny on the technical details of how to register and vote. The Globe & Mail has a Coles Notes version of the various party platforms. And this handy site will break down for you the strategic voting options in your riding (if you plan on going ABC). Every vote counts for something. Even if the person you vote for doesn't win their riding, your vote still helps their popular support numbers (the thought does count!) and gains them funding. Heck, vote for the Canada Heritage Party, if that's what twists your widget. Spoil or refuse your ballot if you are so fed up with the whole system that you could scream. But vote! Voters are registering in record numbers down south, but what's going on in the US is not any more important and impactful to our lives than what's going on up here. We may not have the excitement of Palin or Obama, but what's happening this Tuesday, especially in this climate of global turmoil, will impact how Canada develops as a country against this backdrop. We're electing history-makers!

1. Put your playlist on random (or whatever passes for "random" on winamp) 2. Post the first line from the first 45 (skippings songs you don't feel like using, of course) 3. Get your friends to guess what song the line belongs to (if they're as bored as you are) 4. Give credit when someone guesses correctly (because it may be the most they ever achieve in life) 1. I'm trying to tell you something about my life / maybe give me insight between black and white Guessed by Closer to Fine, Indigo Girls 2. I want somebody who sees the pointlessness but still keeps their purpose in life / I want somebody who has a tortured soul / some of the time Guessed by Asking Too Much, Ani DiFranco 3. Truth is, I thought it mattered / I thought the music mattered Guessed by Tubthumpin', Chumba Wumba 4. Squint your eyes and look closer / I'm not between you and your ambition Guessed by 32 Flavours, Ani DiFranco 5. All night / all I hear / all I hear's your heart Furnace Room Lullaby, Neko Case 6. I've got money in my pocket / I like the colour of my hair / I've got a friend who loves me Guessed by Good Mother, Jann Arden 7. How can I go home with nothing to say / I know you're going to look at me that way You Had Time, Ani DiFranco 8. Life in the circus ain't easy / but the folks on the outside don't know Guessed by Freakshow, Ani DiFranco 9. It's the perfect time of year / somewhere far away from here Guessed by , , and Pinch Me, Barenaked Ladies 10. If I should stay / well, I would only be in your way / and so I'll go Guessed by I Will Always Love You, Dolly Parton 11. Big girls don't cry / big girls don't cry Guessed by Big Girls Don't Cry, Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons 12. Born a normal child / but the dream, it didn't last long Born Normal, Dispatch 13. Broke into the old apartment / this is where we used to live Guessed by and The Old Apartment, Barenaked Ladies 14. He had all kind of reasons / why she was unable to love him / she was just too young / she was too headstrong Unrequited, Ani DiFranco 15. Wash away my troubles / wash away my pain / with rain of Shambala Guessed by Shambala, Three Dog Night 16. Oh Mario / sit here by the window / stay here 'til we reach Idaho Guessed by Pavlov's Bell, Aimee Mann 17. Old John the Baptist / old John divine / leather harness 'round his line John Saw That Number, Neko Case 18. I am not a pretty girl / that is not what I do Guessed by and Not a Pretty Girl, Ani DiFranco 19. Bicycle / bicyle / bicycle / I want to ride my bicycle Guessed by Bicycle, Queen 20. Don't ask me why I'm crying / I'm not gonna tell you what's wrong Letter to a John, Ani DiFranco 21. Oh, death has been your lover / he has brought you the edges of your life On Every Corner, Ani DiFranco 22. I'm still here because I got nothing else to do / you're an asshole but I'm getting used to you Guessed by Puddle Dive, Ani DiFranco 23. In the jukebox of her memory / the list of names flips by and stops Guessed by Jukebox, Ani DiFranco 24. Fear no more the heat of the sun / nor the furious winters' rages / thou thy worldly task hast done / home art gone and taken thy wages Cymbeline, Loreena McKennitt 25. I heard the sound of your bike / as your wheels hit the gravel / then your engine in the driveway cutting off Guessed by and Gravel, Ani DiFranco 26. I'm not gonna be afraid / don't be afraid / I'm not gonna be afraid / don't be afraid / I will not be afraid / to let my talent / shine Guessed by Hat Shaped Hat, Ani DiFranco 27. What's with that halo hovering / above that thick skull Shrug, Ani DiFranco 28. I cannot name this / I cannot explain this / and I really don't want to Guessed by Shameless, Ani DiFranco 29. Every day is so wonderful / and suddenly, it's hard to breathe Beautiful, Elvis Costello (cover) 30. The world is a vampire / sent to drain Guessed by and Bullet with Butterfly Wings, Smashing Pumpkins 31. Mahatten is an island / like the women who are / surrounded by children in a car surrounded by cars Reprieve, Ani DiFranco 32. Company / always on the run / destiny / is a rising sun Bad Company, Bad Company 33. One / one / two / two / one two three four! Girl Anachronism, Dresden Dolls (okay, that one wasn't really fair) 34. The sirens are screaming and the fires are howling / way down in the valley tonight Guessed by and Bat Out of Hell, Meat Loaf 35. When superstars and cannonballs are running through your head / television freak show cops and robbers everywhere Guessed by and The Animal Song, Savage Garden 36. Who's sorry now / who's sorry now / who's heart is aching for breaking each vow Guessed by Who's Sorry Now, Connie Francis 37. Indian summer, I believe / you were new in town / I was nineteen Dark Horse, Mila Mason 38. What does it mean to break out of a dream and be wearing someone else's shorts The Same Thing, Barenaked Ladies 39. You broke my heart / 'cause I couldn't dance / you didn't even want me around Guessed by Do You Love Me (Now that I Can Dance)?, The Contours 40. Say your prayers, little one / don't forget, my son, to include everyone Guessed by Enter Sandman, Metallica 41. I am the fountain of affection / I'm the instrument of joy Guessed by When I'm Up (I Can't Get Down), Great Big Sea 42. You and I are betting on words / you and I are wandering worlds / apart from each other Guessed by and Cosmic Dare, The Seatbelts 43. Turn around / look at what you see / in her face / the mirror of your dreams Guessed by and Never-Ending Story, Limahl 44. So many people live in my town / and mind to my business but none of their own Mood to Burn Bridges, Neko Case 45. You look the part of / the poor brave martyr / and guess who broke your heart Sugar-Coated, Aimee Mann

The fact is, living is about moving.  Some part of me believes that man invented time-keeping as a monument to this very fact.  So when I encounter a moment of the absolute sensation of life, I struggle to think of a way to memorialize it myself.

The dilemma is Heisenberg's -- to measure and record the facts of something so small as a moment is to irrevocably alter its action and essence, thereby rendering the true measure impossible.  To take a picture or write a description, however poetic or well-framed, is to necessitate the stepping out of a moment in order to observe it through a mechanical object, rather than experience it with immediacy, and to later visit its altered form in order to verify an experience one did not truly have.  Thus, human memory is not reproductive, but constructive, such that we never have the same memory twice, and even the cherished ones are new moments, experienced again for the first time, and new moments are uncapturable, like trying to draw the same cup of water twice from the same stream.

Yet these moments define us, enrich us, make us awestruck, and bring us unfathomable joy, and I wish to keep them, somehow, because the totality of the human endeavour is our struggle with the finite nature of things we wish would last forever.  I find myself at odds with these moments, these awed encounters, and I rush to open every sense, every thought, every pore, efficient as a desert plant in the midst of an unpredictable rain shower, while at the same time attempt to devise a trap, a permanent store of this love and awe and life.  Inevitably, the only sufficient homage I can invent for these moments are tears, themselves a mystery, a boon, a sacrifice, uniquely and universally human, and transient.

So I'm stuffing my yaw with stuffing, mashed potato, stuffing, coleslaw, and some stuffing (and cranberry sauce!), when there's a discovery in our kitchen! Our chicken is green. The meat close to the backbone and into the breast is a bright and inexplicable olive green. Well, there goes my drumstick. My current theories are 1) process using industrial dye in factory (maybe for tagging/identifying produce?) has gone awry, and 2) some kind of dye in the feed resulting in overdose. Who knows. It doesn't look natural, either in colour or pattern. Meat wasn't outdated and looked all right every other way. Mother's calling public health tomorrow and then taking it back to the grocery store. Bleh. I wanted that drumstick. Thank goodness for stuffing!

Oh, Globe and Mail -- you may lie and misrepresent like every other media outlet, but you occasionally have hilarious help columns. One dude's problem: I met this dude in school and we've been friends for 10 years. But the last time we spoke I had that feeling - a bit like the feeling you get when your significant other is about to break up with you. I'm thinking the bromance is over. [...] I don't talk to my wife about this because it has a tinge of gay to it. I mean, why would one dude be all knotted about another dude not calling him back, right? The columnnist replies: If your "bromance" is starting to fade, maybe you should invite him out on a "man-date," and "bropose" to him, then the two of you can get "manried" and head off to a tropical "mancation" destination for a bromantic "manlimoon." [...] Also, I guess I'm poking a bit of fun at the "brocabulary" of man-prefixed terms that have been in vogue lately. But I think I've got it out of my system now. [...] There's nothing wrong with loving your male friends. I have several male friends I'd be crushed to lose. If one of them said he was finally fed up with me and my antics, my heart would be bro-ken (okay, it's not out of my system). I'd have to walk around in the rain so no one could see I was crying, my manscara (okay, it's never going to stop) running down my cheeks. [...] Does that make me any less mantastic? Any less heterolicious? I don't see why it should. [...] So don't be afraid of making a "broverture" to your buddy. [...] Go for it. Run, run like the wind, like a guy at the end of a bromantic comedy - or better yet borrow a motorcycle and zoom to his house, popping wheelies, the music swelling as you ride up on the sidewalk, weaving in and out of pedestrians and knocking over fruit stands - and materialize in his doorway with a UFC DVD in one hand and a six-pack in the other and, your face working with emotion, say to him: "Dude, it's killing me how we never hang any more." Hang your heart out there. Show him how you feel. You've got nothing to lose, in my opinion, but your well-founded feelings of manxiety at the prospect of losing a good, old friend. Okay, I'm really going to stop now. Oh, the man-pain. (One person in the comments found the columnist to be offensive toward gays, and to that I say TTTTTTTHHHHHHHHHHHHPPPPPP. Obviously making fun of heteropanic, not homofabulous.)
Livejournal is no longer offering free no-ad accounts. Existing basic accounts will not be changed.

So sometimes I have this thought: If I ever needed to confirm [so-and-so's] identity by asking them a personal question the answer to which only [so-and-so] would know, I would totally ask them [random trivia]! You know the scenarios I'm talking about: reincarnation, body possession, body-swapping, speaking from beyond the grave, alien impersonation, etc. I have these thoughts all the time, but they usually slip my mind within a few hours. I'm trying to think of them all again, for kicks. For Bina, I would totally just say, "Duncan?" And for Amy, it would have to be, "Lemons?" I have about six thousand for Val, but I'm drawing a blank on them right now. Ditto for Caleb. But I've had these thoughts about all of you at some point! So in case anyone ever impersonates you or you ever have to speak through another person's body, I am totally down with it. That is all.

Last chance to get points in my song lyric meme challenge -- no definitive winner yet! Totally up for grabs still. Possible prizes include music from the list (your choice), baked goods, hugs, a silly arts and crafts project, or maybe even, if you happen to have a burning question in the area of the soft sciences, a mini-research project! (It makes me cry to realize that baking, crafts, and lit reviews are my strengths. I fail.) I'm going to post the answers and unscreen the comments on Monday evening.

My mummy got new pyjamas for Christmas, so now she looks like the blue teddy bear from Duckman. I giggled myself silly while rubbing her belly and calling her a plush toy. That made her awfully disgruntled and she proceeded to do an interpretive Care Bear Stare. (Meaning she doesn't know what that is, but she gave it her all. She kind of looked like a demented ewok.) Watching Xena again. I'm caught between loving the all-out woman!lovefest that this show is (both for women in general and for women who love women), and feeling a little sad that Hercules and Iolaus didn't get to have near so much fun, even of the platonic hugging/snuggling/saying-"I love you"-a-bunch-of-times variety. Then I remember Torchwood and the universe evens out. Also, buckets of cheese. Made of dork! Oh, Sam Raimi -- you're so obvious in everything you do, or are even peripherally involved in, and it's usually wonderful. Usually. (My mum is so cute, I just want to cuddle her to DEATH.)

*IMMENSE IRRITATION* I don't know what pisses me off more: the frat boys or this guy defending them with asinine semantics. (Not that I don't love semantics, but he's, uhm, WRONG -- "slut" is not a completely harmless word that some crack-brained feminists have decided to interpret hysterically just 'cuz. Frankly, the OED is off its game with this word -- I checked the definition and it is definitely missing some contemporary usage, which is decidedly more sexual and more negative.) This guy is off his nut if he really thinks his interpretation of the event is harmless: The fact is that the young Zeta Psi pledges in question are fantasizing: I'm sure they would love to find a few promiscuously inclined babes hanging around the Women's Center, but they probably couldn't get a Yale woman to have sex with them if they got down on their knees and wept for it. So they will fantasize about meeting some of the more sexually active of the 5700 women students at Yale (many of whom will doubtless outshine them academically; it's tough life), and at night they will masturbate in their dorm rooms as normal, and by day they will sometimes find ways to be casually offensive to girls in standard college-boy manner, and the First Amendment will protect them if they announce their fantasies on Facebook.com, and the world will go on turning, and the sky will not fall, and I really don't think anyone needs to go to court about such things. Surely Yale women can find more important lawsuits to work on than this. Frankly, I don't believe that freedom of speech should act as diplomatic immunity. People are responsible for the consequences of their actions. That kind of demonstration in front of the goddamned Women's Center is not a healthy expression of opinion -- it's a juvenile stunt with the potential of harming young women seeking help. The women of that campus weren't immune to the consequences of these actions, so why should the men be? I really hope the school is taking action. Then again, the fact that this guy is so completely off-base in his assessment of what's going on (in the article he recants as soon as he sees a picture that reveals the frat boys to be "a dozen unsavory-looking guys looking roughly like street gang members blocking the door of a building in which rape counseling takes place", emphasis mine -- apparently he assumed these Yalies were just decent chaps having a bit of fun, what ho, nevermind that they're actually dressed like every undergrad boy I see on campus every day) kind of makes me less mad at him. I mean, here's a guy who's got his sexism, racism, and classism so out of step with the mainstream that it makes him look less harmless relative to the frat boys who thought this would be a good idea in the first place. I'd be more pissed if he was a policy-maker or celebrity figure -- someone with the social capital to really influence the rest of us. The guest response and the general discussion I've been following in various livejournals are heartening, at least. At least this guy was challenged, even though he still doesn't seem to have gotten the point. Why, why, why did those frat boys think it would be a good idea? Someone please explain. Okay, the sign was dumb, whatever. But why in front of the Women's Center? SUPPLEMENTAL: And then there were the comments. These make me angriest of all. Current winner: "Tasteless? Yes. Sexual harassment? No. Legal action? LOL. Cupcakes at the Women's Center need to worry about more important things... like shaving their pits and finding a boy thirsty enough to lay with them." ARGH. I know it's partly the anonymity of the Interweb giving people the option to say things they might not say otherwise, but GODDAMNIT the opinions are there anyway! And a satire defense doesn't cut it. Satire is context, content, and intent, not just a tag you can affix to any idea you want to express with immunity from retaliation. SUPPLEMENTAL SUPPLEMENTAL: Unrelated, but apparently I'm allergic to studying now. Every time in the last three weeks that I've sat down with a textbook I've started feeling seriously ill within the hour. Now, maybe you say it's just coincidence, 'tis the season for sickery and all, but what do you say to the fact that the only reliable cure seems to be boyporn? It's a conspiracy, says I!

My last two weekends have been made of girl-party.  Pretty damn cool.

I'm in the class of ultimate redundancy!  Fortunately he seems to be covering all the overlap in one go.  But, yeah, the first part of the class is "How to write your research paper" (I wrote one in the sister class to this last semester).  Part two is extra time to work on our first lab assignment, which I wrote last week and had him give a once-over to before class.

I'm not being productive at all right now.  And I'm not really paying attention either.  Kinda feel like a jerk!  Ah well.  He knows I have nothing else to do, and I don't think he really cares, so long as I'm not a distraction.  Damn noisy keyboard though.

Whoops, new info!  Paying attention now.

I'm shy a couple of books right now. Did I happen to lend out She's Come Undone, Wally Lamb, or Wicked, Gregory Maguire, to anyone recently, just before suffering a massive bout of amnesia? I know I saw Wicked recently at least, as I showed it to Val. But she definitely only borrowed House of Leaves. Anyone? Anyone? I'm scared they ran away. SUPPLEMENTAL: Today's winner of the Unbelievable Stupidity award. *headdesk* Telling students that they'll get $5000 dollars at graduation if they don't smoke through high school (based on the sponsers they find). So many reasons why that would NEVER EVER WORK. Actually, according to the over-justification effect, it might even make more kids smokers, because it conceptually increases the value of smoking ("Wow, smoking is worth $5000 dollrs! It must be wicked cool, or they'd never pay me that much!").

My family is awesome and I have a sparkly princess ring.  Yay!

(A number of people have told me that my favourite little cousin on my mum's side is just like me.  Joy!  He's a ten-year-old who loves school and listens to Led Zeppelin.  He also has volume control issues.)

And Bina's going to marry into the family.  Granny and I were match-making.

Ten years ago today I would have been going out of my mind with excitement. Hell, five years ago today and I would have been at least a little giddy. Age 21, and I'm boy-cotting Christmas. Not deliberately and not on my own (Mother is just as gleeful as I am at the thought of neither putting up nor taking down a single decoration and Bina is a self-described Grinch), and certainly not with any amount of venom or attempts at political commentary -- we're just skipping Christmas this year. A little bit of Christmas music here and there, but Mother never unpacked her nativity and I've totally flubbed gift-giving (working on that still). It just doesn't feel like Christmas this year. *shrug* Happy holidays to the world, though. It's just another Tuesday for me. (Actually, I'm kind of wondering if it might possibly be related to the drought of Stephen Colbert's "attacks on Christmas" series.) SUPPLEMENTAL: Edited to include one of the more hilarious things I've read today. I've been delighted by no fewer than three implausible-yet-brilliant AUs, one of which involved transplanting a sci-fi series into cattle-rancher territory, and it worked, goddamnit.

Hi, guys.  I am around right now, just feeling quiet.

Have a wonderful break, everyone.  ^__^  I wish you all joy.

How I wish I could make a real poll in lj. Anyway, think carefully about your answer before clicking on the link! Which of these was seriously considered as a tactic during WWII? a) anti-tank dogs b) bat bombs c) pigeon-guided missiles Sadly, all of them. No, seriously. Bonus follow-up for keeners: What is B. F. Skinner's full name? Burrhus Frederic Skinner. No wonder he always went by his initials. (Also, the pigeon-guided missiles were totally his idea.) And that's my random psych trivia for the day. Back to writing my awesome, awesome paper.

I could live off of clementines and sticky rice with hot sauce. Just sayin'. Working on updating this with my life, but I'm sort of submerged in studying and studies right now. Will be more informative in a couple weeks? Tragedy of the week: ordering my extra-large tea as usual and getting Earl Grey (drinkable, but definitely not my favourite and definitely a disappointing substitute for orange pekoe). And then going back to buy a replacement, and nearly getting served DECAF. This after eight straight hours on campus (after an ELEVEN hour stint the day before). Same lady both times. She didn't clue in to my despair. I think she thought I was being cute. So. Much. School. It's kinda fun, but, you know, lots. Wow. (I have eaten upwards of seven clementines today alone. I am so not going to get scurvy.) SUPPLEMENTAL: So, the Unborn Victims of Crime Bill. Interesting. I have to admit, one element of this proposed legislation concerns me. First of all, it is intended to apply to anyone (in the commission of a crime against the mother or child, who knows or ought to know the woman is pregnant) who harms an unborn foetus at any stage of development. To be clear, this legislation does not attempt to address the maternal neglect or abuse, nor legal termination or acts of good faith. It does, however, have an exlusionary clause for the defence that the foetus is not a person. And we are talking murder-equivalent consequences here: it calls for no less than ten years and a maximum of life in the most general of circumstances. Now, I don't mean that I think this bill is totally wrong (I really don't), but the schism of concepts between this bill and our abortion legislation gives me pause. There does not seem to be a comfortable fit--is legal abortion operating through just a loophole? It seems like it! I think we need to go back and really address section 7 of the Charter (right to life) and the status of a foetus before we continue on with this kind of law-making, or we could end up with a hell of a mess on our hands and in our courts. I've gone over all three bits of legislation, and they are damn sparse. Maybe the case law would be more enlightening... *sigh* Maybe the loophole approach is best. I'm never sure exactly where I stand on abortion and how I want it to be defined. I don't believe I would abort a child I was carrying, even if I wasn't yet physiologically aware of it--hell, I get attached to miniature kitchen appliances, never mind a tiny blob of cells with the potential to become a human being! So obviously I, personally, think of the things as "people" pretty early on. However, I support legalized abortion and I don't believe women should be required to have children (nor are they murderers for terminating), especially not with the incredible stigma and social pressure of being a young, single mother. Or even young and pregnant! I think anti-abortion legislation should come with reasonable and highly effective measures to support and protect the women affected by it (unlikely!). Man, I also keep coming back to my theme of "what makes a person?". More on that in a later post. A multitude of converging thoughts, avalanche of cognition.

Thank you to everyone who has responded to my scenario query from yesterday. You guys were very open and helpful and I've gathered some interesting insights. Anyone who is interested may still, of course, contribute. Your unsolicited compensation takes the form of a hilarious YouTube video: the many names of David Ryder!

Okay, now I'm spamming, but Bina said this and for once I ended up with a subject line and no content.

*shrug*

You are seated on a full bus. The seat beside you is the last free one; you are seated near the front of the bus. At the next stop, the only person to board is obese. You observe that this person clearly cannot fit in a single bus seat. a) Do you give up your seat or stay seated? How would your response change if: b) the obese person asks you politely if you would give up your seat? c) the obese person is carrying a McDonald's take-out bag? d) the obese person is a woman? e) the obese person is older (50+)? f) the obese person is well-dressed (e.g. tailored pant suit)? g) there is another available seat at the back of the bus that you could take? ~~~ Responses are appreciated, and elaborated responses are especially appreciated. Don't feel constrained by my presented format; it's more for organization than anything else. Your personal reactions are encouraged. Comments are screened and anonymous commenting is allowed. This is not intended to criticize any person; I am objectively interested in people's feelings and intentions in this situation. Those interested in a more implicit measure (i.e. of unconscious, automatic associations that are difficult to "fake" and do not always correspond with our conscious feelings and beliefs) may find the weight IAT (Implicit Association Task) at the Harvard IAT website interesting. Follow that link and scroll until you find it (the list order randomizes itself). EDIT: section g) added.

It's Monday night, so I'm indulging in reality TV.  Dragon's Den, Dirty Jobs, and Canada's Worst Drivers 3.  If only Deadliest Catch and non-repeat Mythbusters were on too.

Also, over-dosing on citrus.  I've eaten five clementines today, and I may yet eat more.

I had more fun in my experimental analysis and methods class than usual.  I had a meeting with a professor and didn't come out of it feeling like a total dork!  I think he likes me more than he was letting on.

My hands are not getting enough blood.  Scary.

I miss the nice weather.  I wish I had spent more time outside studying.

I can't decide if I like Mike Rowe better when he's surprisingly competent and adorably delighted, or when he's predictably useless and self-deprecatingly snarky.  I just wanna keep him.

No one tell Bina I said this: quack.

I get money this weekend!  Excitement!  I wanna go book-buying to celebrate.

Okay, this one is for all the sci-fi/fantasy fiends on my flist (which should be, uhm, all of you?): Is there still some small, tiny, incessant part of you that insists that somewhere, when, or how, your favourite tv series/book/movie is actually true? Be it of Jedi knights or vampire slayers, does something within you refuse to relent to the voice of "reason" when it comes to the viability of your favourite fantastical world? How many of you are waiting to say I knew it! when the it's all true finally comes your way? Nothing faster induces reflective melancholy in me than finishing a long book or series. It feels much like grief and longing. Some days I just really want alien spaceships to appear on the horizon. SUPPLEMENTAL: Specifics are encouraged, if it's not too personal. For my part, I've had a few over the years, but none quite so strongly as SG-1 and SGA. Possibly because of the real-time and plausibility factor that have deliberately been worked into the series. I really just want people to be that brilliant and cranky. Okay, and when I was nine I had an on-going delusion about DBZ.

Also, I lost a game of chicken to a squirrel.  But it was a downtown squirrel, so I think my manhood is still intact.

Fuckin' ballsy rodent.
